greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Smallest number of triangular numbers which sum to n.
comment: a(n)=3 if n=5 or 8 mod 9, since triangular numbers are {0,1,3,6} mod 9.
link: Giovanni Resta, Table of n, a(n) for n = 0..10000
formula: a(n) = 0 if n=0, otherwise 1 if n is in A000217, otherwise 2 if n is in A051533, otherwise 3 in which case n is in A020757.
example: a(3)=1 since 3=3, a(4)=2 since 4=1+3, a(5)=3 since 5=1+1+3, with 1 and 3 being triangular.
mathematica: t[n_]:=n*(n+1)/2; a[0]=0; a[n_]:=Block[ {k=1, tt= t/@ Range[Sqrt[2*n]]}, Off[IntegerPartitions::take]; While[{} == IntegerPartitions[n, {k}, tt, 1], k++]; k]; a/@ Range[0, 104] (* _Giovanni Resta_, Jun 09 2015 *)
program: (PARI) see A283370 for generic code, working but not optimized for this case of triangular numbers. - _M. F. Hasler_, Mar 06 2017
xref: Cf. A104246 (analog for A000292), A283365 (analog for A000332), A283370 (analog for A000389).
results.author: _Henry Bottomley_, Apr 25 2001
